nodes.text: Introduce government debt into a neoclassical two-period lived overlapping generations growth model to analyze long-run effects of external and internal national debt on competitive equilibrium and individual utility

Model setup: discrete time economy with infinite horizon, constant-returns-to-scale aggregate production F(K,L)=L f(k), no depreciation, two-period lived individuals with utility U(c1,c2), population growth rate n, and competitive factor markets

Government debt specification and financing: government issues only one-period debt paying current interest rate, debt-labor ratio is held constant by refinancing plus lump-sum taxes on the young to finance residual interest

Equilibrium characterization: capital market equilibrium equates aggregate saving to next period capital plus government demand for internal debt; factor-price frontier relates wages and interest via production; long-run equilibria (Golden Age paths) have constant capital-labor ratio

Competitive solution can be dynamically inefficient: long-run competitive equilibrium interest rate may differ from growth rate n so capital-labor ratio can exceed Golden Rule level and welfare could be increased by reducing capital

Individual behavior and saving: younger generation supplies capital via s = S(w,r), where s is differentiable, 0 < ds/dw < 1 and ds/dr may be positive or negative depending on preferences and technology

Assumptions used for comparative statics and stability: single stable equilibrium, downward-sloping capital demand f'(k), and sign conditions on derivatives ensure comparative-static signs of interest and wage responses

External debt effect specification: externally held debt only affects domestic economy via taxes required to pay interest abroad; taxes per worker equal (r - n) times external debt-labor ratio g1 in long-run equilibrium

Internal debt effect specification: internally held debt affects supply (taxes) and demand (government floats debt in domestic capital market), substituting government paper for physical capital and directly reducing domestic capital stock

Mechanism: taxes reduce disposable lifetime consumption and reduce savings, lowering capital stock; changes in capital stock alter factor prices (w and r) via the factor-price frontier and thus affect individual utility

Result on external debt (normal/efficient case r>n): external debt reduces lifetime utility of a representative individual in long-run equilibrium because taxes lower consumption and because taxes shift equilibrium interest rate away from growth rate, reducing welfare

Result on internal debt (normal/efficient case r>n): internal debt lowers utility and raises the equilibrium interest rate because government demand for loanable funds crowds out physical capital and taxes also reduce saving and capital

Comparative result: internal debt causes a larger decline in individual utility than equivalent external debt in the normal efficient case, because internal debt combines tax effects with substitution of paper for capital reducing output

Debt swap (replace external by internal debt) result: swapping external for internal debt raises equilibrium interest rate and, in the efficient case, reduces individual utility because higher r increases tax burden and further reduces capital

Ambiguity in inefficient case (r<n): when competitive equilibrium is dynamically inefficient (r < n), effects of external and internal debt on utility can reverse sign and may raise or lower utility depending on parameter values and slopes of saving/demand curves

Model limitations and critical assumptions: results rely on one-period debt, debt refloated at current rate, constant debt-labor ratio, lump-sum taxes on young, absence of bequests, and assumed stability and slope signs of supply and demand for capital
